author: @NA12495
text: import RPi.GPIO as GPIO import time  GPIO.setmode(GPIO.BCM)  TRIG = 4 ECHO = 18  GPIO.setup(TRIG, GPIO.OUT) GPIO.setup(ECHO, GPIO.IN)  GPIO.output(TRIG, True) time.sleep(0.0001) GPIO.output(TRIG, False)  while GPIO.input(ECHO) == False:     start = time.time()  while GPIO.input (ECHO) == True:     end = time.time()  sig_time = end - start  #cm: distance = sig_time / 0.000058  #inches: 0.00048  print ('Distance: {} cm'.format(distance))  GPIO.cleanup()      Error, line 22 name  'end' is not defined.  It worked a few times... don't know if it is the code, maybe a difference in versions or hardware.  annoying either way

author: @okiseeyou
text: ran into a weird issue where every other time the program ran, one of the WHILE loops would not run and it threw an error since the Start or End times would not be defined. For anyone else experiencing this issue, adding the following 2 lines immediately after the GPIO.setup seems to fix this.       GPIO.output(TRIG, False)     time.sleep(0.1)   Hope that helps, I was pulling my hair out for an hour.

text: I'm puzzled, perhaps someone can help:  a) where do we get the 0,000058 from?  b) why are we dividing and not multiplying?  I was taught at school that:  distance = speed of sound * elapsed time  1) speed of sound at 20*C is 343 m/s -- we want to know the distance in cm, so we have to convert 343 m/s = 34 300 cm/s 2) elapsed time... shouldn't we divide by 2... since sound wave emitted by the sensor makes a round-trip (from sensor - to object - back to sensor)? 3)... I'm clueless. :(
